keyTakeAways: A Colombian appeals court overturned the conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe for fraud and bribery, citing structural deficiencies in the original verdict and insufficient evidence.
The decision is seen as a major shift in Colombia’s judicial landscape, with critics arguing it may cover up the role of right-wing paramilitaries in the country’s conflict history.
Uribe, a controversial figure known for his military campaigns against left-wing rebels, has long been accused of enabling or covering up paramilitary abuses, including witness manipulation.
The case has intensified political divisions in Colombia, with former President Gustavo Petro accusing the judiciary of protecting politicians aligned with paramilitary networks.
Senator Ivan Cepeda has announced plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court of Justice, indicating the case is far from concluded.

The ruling has drawn international attention, particularly from U.S. political figures like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, who have criticized Colombia’s judicial system as biased against conservatives.

Petro, the current left-wing president, fears that the decision may strengthen ties between U.S. right-wing forces and Colombian political elites, potentially leading to U.S. sanctions or policy shifts.

Uribe’s party, the Democratic Center, has indicated he will run for senator if legally possible, and Senator Cepeda has signaled a presidential candidacy, suggesting significant political realignments ahead.
The case may have lasting implications for Colombia’s upcoming 2026 presidential election, with legal outcomes shaping party alliances and public sentiment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Colombian appeals court has overturned the conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe on charges of fraud and bribery, citing structural flaws and insufficient evidence in the original ruling. The decision follows years of legal and political contention, with critics accusing the judiciary of protecting right-wing figures and covering up paramilitary abuses. Uribe, known for his military campaigns against leftist rebels, has long denied wrongdoing, and the reversal has reignited political divisions, particularly between left-wing President Gustavo Petro and right-wing allies. Senator Ivan Cepeda plans to appeal to Colombia’s Supreme Court, signaling the case is far from concluded. The outcome may significantly influence Colombia’s 2026 presidential election and has drawn international attention from U.S. figures like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, who have criticized the Colombian judicial system as biased against conservatives. The case underscores ongoing tensions between judicial independence, political power, and historical accountability in Colombia.
title: Colombian appeals court strikes down ex-President Uribe’s conviction
